reviewText:
Nice retro-style shoot-em-up (shmup) with a twist.

In this game the levels consist of colored monsters that just sit there, and when you shoot them they turn into gems to collect.  But some of them turn light blue and are indestructable.  There are other obstacles like rocks and moving enemies to avoid or kill.  Making your way through the maze is difficult.  There are dead ends and if you choose the wrong path, the screen is slowly scrolling down and you can be trapped.  Each time it is randomly generated, so don't bother trying to memorize.  Collect gems but don't take too much time trying to get them all or you will get trapped!  Some enemies drop special icons that you use to upgrade your ship.  Also one enemy in the bunch will drop the Emerald that you need to get

The thing I love about this game is that even if you die you keep all the stuff you collected!  That's right up my alley because I'm not that good at these games.  Use the gems to buy new ships and upgrade the defense, attack, and speed of your chosen ship.  Some ships come with special benefits that are useful on certain planets.

Each planet has the gem collect level and then a boss section.  The boss is typical bullet hell, though not as bad as some I've seen.  When you finish a boss new ships are unlocked for purchase.  You can do the planets in any order.

Graphics:  Nice pixel graphics.  I like how they have the different colored layers in the tunnel to make it look like 3D.  The sprites are cute.

Sound:  There is a narrator in the beginning intro scene and at the start of each level he says something.  You can turn him off if you don't want to listen to it.  The normal pew-pew sounds and background music that sounds retro.

Controller worked fine for me.  I used an Xbox controller on Windows 7 PC.

Final Thoughts:  Might be a little too easy for a pro shmupper, but nice for us regular folks.  It's cheap!  Nice to see a dev that doesn't over-price their games.
voteText: 17 of 17 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Super Star Path is a brilliant fusion between a shoot 'em up and a color match puzzler. The clever way this marriage is implemented though, is really what elevates it beyond the sum of it parts.

It's not just simply blasting waves of enemies to reach the boss, it's about carefully carving a path for your ship to make it through. When you shoot an enemy of a certain color, it's adajcent color matches will explode in a chain. When the chain finally hits an enemy of different color, it will end and turn that enemy into a crystal which you are not able to destroy.

What does that mean exactly? Careless volleys can leave you with a dead end. This principle mechanic for traversing through levels requires you to take precise shots, and plan ahead for survival. Things get even more interesting when other level specific hazards are introduced as well as more traditional enemies. Once you wrap your head around the flow of the game, it's a sublime experience.

The presentation too is stellar. With colorful, vibrant pixel art evocative of the Super Nintendo era and a top notch chiptune soundtrack ranging from melancholic, hypnotic tones to upbeat, excitement builiding battle music.

The asking price is so reasonable that it should be a no brainer for most. You should pick it up!

Check out my video of the game for more details!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=twfLbYvgHvw

reviewText: At first, this game is extremely frustrating and difficult. The levels are generated randomly, and they come at you seemingly blazingly fast. In addition to the match/freeze puzzle mechanic that separates this game from other shmups, there are some standard enemies tossed at you at the same time, and they take several hits, which makes for a hectic and somewhat annoying gameplay experience.\n\nHOWEVER... As soon as you lock into the swing of things, you will be collecting gems and upgrades for your ships. If you hang in there long enough to beat a boss, you will unlock more ships with abilities above and beyond those found in the initial two that are available. It is, needless to say, a game-changer, to have the ability to be immune to certain types of enemy bullets, or to have the ability to break the previously-indestructible blocks that impede your path. This opens things up, lets you breathe a little, and have a much better time. I quickly went from my typical 5-minutes-and-I-give-up gamer A.D.D. attitude, to aww man
date: my wife is home with the groceries... Guess I'd better quit for now and help her bring them in and put them away."\n\nI am still pretty early on in the game
recommended: but I didn't want to wait with sharing my recommendation for this new release. For the asking price
hoursPlayed: I feel that this is a great little vertical-scrolling shmup
voteText: with day-one Linux release and gamepad support out of the box (I am using xboxdrv with a lovely Nexus Gamepad).  The only thing I noticed is that I don't hear sound effects (music is fine)
helpfulPercent: which I will report to the devs and hopefully will be patched."

reviewText: A really fun puzzle/ shoot 'em up game.  10 different ship to unlock, and a number of upgrades to collect and use. The game is more shooter than puzzle, but requires you to lightly strategize to make your way through the cluster of aliens. The game is not too difficult and hardcore shoot 'em up fans should probably skip this one.  I really love the pixel art graphics, and the minimal voiceover is a nice addition as well.

reviewText:
Stylistically, this game is a substantial accomplishment.  I enjoyed many aspects of the graphics and sound. Unfortunately, this game has many flaws.   I am not sure if I feel compelled to play it again after about an hour of mild enjoyment (punctuated by frustration - and not the good kind.)

- Each stage is divided into a puzzle portion and a boss (bullet hell) portion.  The controls for the ship for the grid-based puzzle portion, however, are almost identical to the boss portion (normal shmup ship controls) which is not well-suited to action puzzle gameplay.  You constantly have to nudge your ship, and maneuvering into gaps in the automatically-scrolling stage is awkward.  I understand the need to dodge bullets, but I think this problem could have been handled more elegantly.
- The ship is destroyed too easily by being crushed".  In fact your ship begins to explode well before hitting the bottom of the screen.  There should be some wiggle room!
- The stages are randomly generated
recommended: there is absolutely no way forward no matter which monsters you shoot.  This happened at least 10 times in my play session.  There is no escape route; your only option is to take your inevitable death.  I suppose the developers thought that not having an Lives made this a non-issue
hoursPlayed: but I would beg to differ.\n- In the same vein
voteText: monsters that shoot at you are sometimes placed in a position where they cannot be destroyed by your pea shooter
helpfulPercent: which only shoots up.  There are no other weapons in the game as far as I can tell.\n- Shooting-enemies don't stand out.  You can't be hurt by normal enemies but you can by the shooting ones.  Avoiding them is a needle-in-haystack affair.\n- Because you're so busy shooting and collecting gems
votesHelpful: finding a powerup or an emerald is 90% of the time a matter of luck.\n- There is very little incentive to get better at spotting these special enemies because of the infinite lives and the fact that you keep everything you pick up even if you die.  But when you really need a powerup to defeat a boss or get through a level
votesTotal: you pretty much have to replay it over and over hoping you stumble upon it.\n- I liked the music and voiceover for the most part
votesFunny: but the pilot banter got old fast.  The cursing is totally unnecessary and just comes across as immature.  The worst of the audio's sins
column17: is the use of SFXR or BFXR.  Those tinny
column20: and tinkles killed what the sound had going for it and the sense of Playstation/Sega Saturn era sophistication.\n\nIf it were a 10 star system I would give it a weak 7
column21: but I cannot recommend this game.  The gameplay is just not very deep at all and doing well is mostly a matter of a roll of the dice due to a noticeable lack of polish in that department.\n\nI encourage the developers to make their next game and improve in that area."

reviewText:
After realizing I just didn't pay much attention to the tutorial, I can reccommend this game.

I previously had a frustrating experience with crstallized enemies blocking my way entirely, making it impossible to continue, and I thought it was just a luck based mechanic. It's not luck based, there is actually an entire system in place (it teaches you about it in the start of the game with a short text tutorial)

I can now say this game is great, and I will enjoy 100%ing it.




*****************PREVIOUS REVIEW BELOW******************************

The game would be fantastic if they didn't hinge level progression on a broken RNG battle.

When you kill an enemy, there is a random chance they will turn into crystal, making them pure walls and unable to be killed. Because of this, you can block yourself from flying any further, forcing yourself to die and restart another boring ride to the boss that will kill you 10+ times before you get ahold of his patterns.

I've had the walls without escape happen over 20 times, and am taking screenshots for people curious to see what I mean.


It's insanely furstrating to play with this RNG mess, I can't reccommend it.

reviewText:
Cheap and cheerful little hybrid vertical shmup and puzzle game, where you shoot your way through levels which you need to navigate like a puzzle, then face a bullet-hell style boss.

There are items to collect. Ships to buy. Upgrades to install.

The controls, graphics, and sound (full voice) are all good quality, the only drawback is that the game is somewhat short. You'll probably be done within about 2 hours.

reviewText:
Excellent pocket-sized shooter that requires a bit of trigger control: Shoot at everything you see and you wont be getting far as targets need to be picked so you can chain-destroy as many as you can to clear a path for your ship to advance.

You will be needing some actual shmup skills too as there is a end boss at the end of every level. Get killed by it and back to the beginning you go.

Very good game considering how simple it is. If i must find something bad then that would be the nasty achievement structure of the game as you wont be bagging any of them until you reach the very end of the game. It is like the whole game is just one big training session until you get to the real deal challenge at the end. (by which time you should also be good enough to pick yourself the ship and upgrades that will save the day) . At 3.99€ normal price this one is easy to recommend.

reviewText:
Fantastic little game with an ingenious and fresh puzzle style mechanic.  The presentation is perfect with incredible art and sound fx and a beautiful, old school soundtrack that holds its own with the best SNES games. Simple, yet solid upgrade system with finding upgrades creating some nice replayability.

The only thing I dont like about SSP is the bosses. The game has such a unique twist, but its thrown tossed aside for the standard, generic bullet hell gameplay for all bosses. It would have been nice to see the developers find ways to incorporate the mechanics from the rest of the game.

Regardless, Super Star Path is a brilliantly designed and executed game. It may only be 2 hrs long, but its absolutely worth the price of admission. GG!

reviewText:
A short but challenging shmup / match puzzle / bullet hell hybrid.

It is very rare that a shmup demands planning ahead on the fly (even the random generation of enemies is very uncommon), so this is a great game to play if you find most shmups too formulaic.

Though developed by a different group, I have to say this reminded me of Wizorb, as well as a few of Adult Swim Games' titles. If you like those things, you will probably like this.

reviewText:
Super Star Path has a cool hook; a puzzle/shooter combo. Unfortunately that hook doesn't really lend itself to being endlessly playable like other puzzle games nor is it an especially challenging shmup. Let me tell you why.

First and foremost, there is a huge missed opportunity here; there is no arcade/score attack mode. There is a story mode and after you beat that, there is a boss rush mode. I 100% the game in a little over an hour. Mileage may vary some, but I can't see most people spending much more than that on this game, which is a shame because the actual gameplay is solid and the music and graphics are appealing. I get that the game itself is somewhat randomly generated. I get that it may have been technically challenging creating an endless arcade score attack mode. But without it the game is over so quickly that it's hard not to feel a bit ripped off, even at the lower price range. Heck, I got it on sale for $1.99 and I still feel a little ripped off, and I feel like a bad person for admitting that.

Also, small aside, but the game has strong cursing in it for pretty much no reason. The pilot will randomly say a few one liners here and there, and then suddenly he'll drop the f-bomb. It's strange, because he also says heck" every so often

reviewText: There's only an hour or two of game in this one, and there's a distinct split between the puzzle parts (which still have an overhead shooter influence) and the bullet hell parts.  None the less, the puzzle part IS clever, and once you understand the mechanism it's challenging without being unfair.  Worth it for the price I got it for, though otherwise it's not really one I'd necessarily recommend. You won't be disappointed, but you also might not really get your money's worth.\n\n(Note that which enemies are crystlallized after a shot is not random; another reviewer made it sound as though it was.  From what I can tell, there's always a path through, though you can wall yourself in if you're not careful. Also, it does have some vulgarity in some of the random voice clips your pilot throws out; it's unneccessary, but it's also not gratuitous, so as long as you don't have the sound cranked while kids are present it shouldn't be a bother.)

reviewText:
Super Star Path is a great little game !

Mixing Shoot'em up and Puzzle games doesn't sound like an obvious idea, but it works really well in game. Every level is composed of two parts: one where you have to find your way through a maze of enemies (the Puzzle part) and one where you must kill a dangerous boss (the Shoot'em up part).

The real idea of this game is in the Puzzle part: when shooting an alien, you kill it as well as all the other same-colored aliens near him. However, that also crystalised the aliens near by, turning them into indestructible walls. In order to reach the end of the level, you'll have to cleverly choose which aliens to shoot!

In addition of this, you can also buy new ships with specific caracteristics (more powerful, doesn't get hit by small bullets etc.) which you can upgrade using gems you can find in the puzzle parts. You'll also have to collect 3 emeralds in every level in order to finish the game. Then, you'll have to kill every boss with only one HP. Good luck on that!

Tl;dr: Great idea, well executed, great art style and atmosphere, with the only down point of the game being short.

reviewText:
Super Star Path caught my eye because of its appealing pixel art, but I really jumped on board because it is a unique blend of puzzle and shmup. Every level is broken into two parts. You start off confronting masses of multicolored, stationary aliens as you push forward. Shooting them makes them explode in connected colored chains, but there's a catch - if a chain explosion hits an alien of a different color, it will be frozen solid and become an indestructible obstacle. In other words, you can't go into every stage shooting all nilly-willy or else you will create an impassable wall and resign yourself to death. Once you pass the aliens you go into a boss confrontation, where the game turns into a true bullet hell shmup. It's an odd combination juxtaposing planning ahead and methodically cutting through walls of enemies with frantic boss fights requiring raction time and good hand-eye coordination.

Each level has unique stage hazards that make things that much harder, and there are 10 ships you unlock gradually with increased stats and unique features (immunity to certain hazards, gem doubler, etc). Hidden in every stage are three aliens holding upgrade points you can use you increase your ships attack power, hit points, and speed. There are also three black aliens per stage holding green emeralds as per the storyline, and collecting them all will get you the true ending when you beat the final boss.

It's a short game. I beat it completely - every stage, every item, all ships unlocked, boss rush - in about 2 hours. Yet I feel satisfied. It's a tight package, with a great soundtrack to boot. Strangely, you can't reassign upgrade points, and there are a finite amount you can get in the game. And some of the later levels feel cheap with an abundance of hazards and chains of aliens you have to hit just right or end up screwing yourself. But I can forgive its faults because the overall package was worth a couple of moments of frustration.

Pros
- Unique blend of gameplay
- Clean and bright pixel art and color palette
- Awesome retraux soundtrack
- Cheap price

Cons
- Short
- Upgrade points can't be reassigned
- Cheap hazards late in the game
- Some of the ships are useless

I'd love to see a sequel expand on this game's concepts!

reviewText:
There is one glaring flaw in this game that prevents me from giving it the full score I originally wanted: the profanity.

Yes. This game uses both s*** and f*** very frequently and it stunned me when I first heard them.

Super Star Path has all of the aesthetics of a great mid-90's shooter: colorful, vibrant graphics; great music reminiscent of a by-gone era; solid vertical shooting; and a unique implementation of Bejewled style puzzle gameplay. Players scroll upwards, shooting everything in their path. But, there's a twist: wisely choosing which enemies to defeat to grant an optimal path is necessary. Essentially, defeating enemies of a common color results in a chain reaction, thus giving you more room to move. But, every enemy adjacent to the last defeated enemy will turn into a crystal, blocking your way. On top of this, each stage has three power-ups and three emeralds to collect. While this may sound tedious, unlimited lives and continues coupled with a great gameplay choice in allowing players to keep everything they've earned (even if they haven't completed the stage yet) make SSP a very balanced game.

There are a variety of ships to choose from, each granting the player different immunities and power specs (which can be upgraded as long as the power-ups are found.) Simply put, the game has great variety.

But. During gameplay your pilot will speak and comment on the action at hand. When I got hit at one point he exclaimed, What the f*** was that?" Another time he said
date: "I'm too old for this s***" While this may seem dumb and inconsequential
recommended: it's completely unnecessary as he repeats it over and over (especially late game where the challenge increases.) No solid arcade shooter back in the day needed content like that to be good. It's abrasive and it clashes terribly with the colorful 16-bit aesthetic it boasts. I sorely implore the developers to patch those words out. Even if the pilot says the classic
hoursPlayed: "I'm too old for this" and cuts the word out
voteText: it would be fine. As it is though
helpfulPercent: I can't recommend this to everyone because of that content.\n\nSuper Star Path is a fantastic game to play that is limited terribly by the weirdest and most unnecessary inclusion of profanity I've ever seen in a game. Be aware of this when you buy it."

reviewText:
Phew...this was both great AND a disappointment. I bought this in a bundle was desperately waiting for it to be released on steam. Was really looking forward to it AND I really enjoyed most of the game.

The pixel art is perfect, ship hitbox a little big but the many ships are cool. Upgrades for your ships are limited, as well as the upgradability. One thing that bugs me about the ships, at certain points only one ship really makes, but overall it's okay.

Puzzling" through levels feels good and the boss battles are moderately challenging
date: it's a small colorful and fun game worth it's money.\n\nBut still there are things I can't ignore. I really enjoyed the game until I faced Boss Rush Mode. Going through all the bosses with one hit meaning your demise is a bit too much. Uninstalled and ignored the fact of several updates
recommended: I was too ♥♥♥♥♥♥ over that. Thought I'd give it a try and failed miserably until RNG was on my side after lots of tries.\n\nAnother thing is the limited Controller support and a bugged keyboard setting. I understand that some problems can't be taken on easily
hoursPlayed: but not even responding in the discussions is pretty weak when there are only 4-5 ones open (at the time I posted mine)\n\nI do recommend this game for it's style
voteText: looks and rather fresh gameplay...and if you want to 100% it...only under the premise you're resistant to frustration."

reviewText:
Product received for free

An incredibly short sort of color-match puzzle on one hand and a SHMUP on the other. Whenever a boss is reached it's almost as if the puzzle section never existed because of how much of a reflex-incentive game it suddenly becomes. It's even mentioned on the Steam store page that it's short and that it's more puzzle than SHMUP".

There's more control over the movement with a controller than there is using a keyboard. Can't rebind the controls but instead they only give you 3 keyboard control schemes and only 2 controller schemes. I've got more problems with the 2 controller schemes because all that they  use and switch around are (A) and (B) which does "Action" and "Cancel" with "Action" being the "Fire" button when in-game. For a game where you can shoot as fast as you press the button I always figured to put that on the left face button (X) but I don't even get a choice on that matter.

There are 5 missions represented by planets to freely choose from and one unlockable final mission after completing the 5. Each one can be completed in a couple of minutes without having to start over upon death. There's a how-to on how the puzzle works and it's a little harder to actually do properly when put into practice since you're constantly dealing with the auto-scrolling  and trying to stay alive so as not to be crushed by enemies that head toward the bottom of the screen. Once this puzzle section is over though and the boss fight comes then it suddenly becomes a bullet-hell-lite of sorts
date: almost as if the puzzle section just became irrelevant.\nAll of the bosses hardly vary from one another; their attacks are hardly different from one another aside from some very slight speed
hoursPlayed:
& visual changes and each boss always has one bullet spreading attack that's no different from what the previous boss does.
In the puzzle sections for every mission you're supposed to collect three highly limited ship upgrades that you can apply to whatever ship you have and collect these True-Ending-material Emeralds. Once you collect whatever collectibles you find you can die or finish the mission and they'd stay collected so even if you didn't grab all in one run you can go back to the mission and grab 'em. For each mission there are three Emeralds and three upgrades to grab.
Enemies & such that are destroyed in missions drop currency that's only used for buying new & unlocked ships that have different effects and stats from one another. Ships are unlocked upon completion of already uncompleted missions. The upgrades can boost their stats to a specified max but there are more ships & stats than there are upgrades throughout the entire game so you're strongly encouraged to save them until you unlock the final and higher-in-stats ships.

There's not much replayability since all missions & bosses are practically similar to one another and it's a short game overall. After beating the base game you unlock a Boss Rush mode where you're pitted against all the bosses one at a time. Whatever ship you choose for that mode can only take one hit of damage but is highly buffed out everywhere else for quicker kills. After that there's really not much else to do with the game.

Apparently this game has 15 Steam cards even though it hardly takes around 2 hours to 100%. It's got a cool soundtrack and cool visuals but it seems so lacking even at $4. If you're good you can probably get a refund if you complete the entire game and keep the playtime under 2 hours."
voteText: May 24
